sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: In Section 1.1 we give a non-technical introduction to the Nyström method as well as the related column selection problem and the CUR problem. In Section 1.2 we summarize our contributions and list our main results. In Section 1.3 we provide an outline of the rest of this paper.

sections.heading: 1.1 Backgrounds
sections.text:
The Nyström method is a kind of low-rank matrix approximation approach mainly used for speeding up kernel methods. The Nyström method can approximate any given positive semidefinite matrix using only a subset of its columns, so it alleviates the computation and storage problems when the kernel matrix is large in size. The Nyström method has been extensively used in the machine learning community. For example, the Nyström method has been applied to Gaussian process Williams and Seeger (2001), kernel SVM (Kumar et al., 2012, Zhang et al., 2008), spectral clustering (Fowlkes et al., 2004), and kernel PCA (Talwalkar et al., 2008, Zhang et al., 2008, ?).
Williams and Seeger (2001) are the first to use the Nyström method for low-rank matrix approximation. The uniform column selection proposed by Williams and Seeger (2001) is
the simplest but the most widely used in practice (Fowlkes et al., 2004, Talwalkar et al., 2008, Gittens and Mahoney, 2013). Following the work of Williams and Seeger (2001), many uniform and non-uniform sampling techniques are proposed and analyzed (Drineas and Mahoney, 2005, Zhang et al., 2008, Belabbas and Wolfe, 2009, Kumar et al., 2009b,a, Cortes et al., 2010, Li et al., 2010, Talwalkar and Rostamizadeh, 2010, Gittens, 2011, Jin et al., 2011, Mackey et al., 2011, Kumar et al., 2012, Gittens and Mahoney, 2013).
Much work has been done on the upper bounds of the sampling techniques for the Nyström method. Most of the work, e.g., (Drineas and Mahoney, 2005, Li et al., 2010, Kumar et al., 2009a, Jin et al., 2011, Kumar et al., 2012), studied the additive-error bound. By further making assumptions on matrix coherence, better additive bounds were obtained by Talwalkar and Rostamizadeh (2010), Jin et al. (2011), Mackey et al. (2011). However, as was argued in the review paper (Mahoney, 2011), additive-error bounds are less convincing than the relative-error bounds. The recent work of Gittens (2011) provided the relative-error bounds for the first time, and then the bounds were sharpened by Gittens and Mahoney (2013). Furthermore, a method called the ensemble Nyström method was proposed by Kumar et al. (2009a, 2012) to improve the standard Nyström method by combining a collection of sampled columns. The ensemble Nyström method demonstrated significant empirical improvement over the standard Nyström method.
However, the lower error bounds of the Nyström method were largely unknown. To our knowledge, the only known lower bound was established in (Jin et al., 2011, Theorem 4) on the additive-error in spectral norm. However, this lower bound is not quite informative because it lower bounds the additive-error on a matrix with potentially very large norm. We will give technical analyses of this lower bound in Section 4.1.
The Nyström method is closely related to the column selection problem and can benefit from the column selection techniques (Kumar et al., 2012, Gittens and Mahoney, 2013). Column selection has been very widely studied in the literature (Frieze et al., 2004, Deshpande et al., 2006, Drineas et al., 2008, Deshpande and Rademacher, 2010, Boutsidis et al., 2011b, Guruswami and Sinop, 2012). The most advanced relative-error columns selection techniques include the adaptive sampling algorithm in (Deshpande et al., 2006), the nearoptimal algorithm in (Boutsidis et al., 2011b), and the optimal algorithm in (Guruswami and Sinop, 2012) whose upper bound matches the lower bound of column selection problem (Boutsidis et al., 2011a).
The Nyström method is also related to the CUR matrix decomposition which selects both columns and rows to form a low-rank approximation. As well as the Nyström method, CUR is also widely studied in the literature (Goreinov et al., 1997a,b, Stewart, 1999, Tyrtyshnikov, 2000, Drineas, 2003, Drineas et al., 2006, 2008, Mahoney and Drineas, 2009, Bien et al., 2010, Wang and Zhang, 2012). The CUR problem is actually an extension of the Nyström method to a general matrix. We will show in Section 4.3 that the lower error bound of the Nyström method is even worse than the upper bound of the state-of-the-art CUR algorithm in (Wang and Zhang, 2012).

sections.heading: 1.2 Summary of Contributions
sections.text:
In this paper we establish lower bounds, both additive-error and relative-error, for the Nyström method and the ensemble Nyström method. To our knowledge, we are the first
to establish relative-error lower bounds for the Nyström method. Interestingly, two of our relative-error lower bounds can be attain by some algorithms in (Gittens and Mahoney, 2013), which indicates the two lower bounds are tight and the corresponding upper bounds (Gittens and Mahoney, 2013) are near optimal.
We summarize the lower bounds in the table below. Here A denotes the original matrix, Ã denotes the approximation to A, Ak denotes the best rank-k approximation to A.

‖A−Ã‖2 ‖A−Ak‖2 ‖A−Ã‖∗ ‖A−Ak‖∗

The lower bounds marked with ‘⋆’ are tight; the tightness of the rest lower bounds are unknown at present. The blanks indicate the lower bounds are unknown to us; we conjecture that the lower bounds of the ensemble Nyström method are identical to the standard Nyström method.

sections.heading: 1.3 Organization of This Paper
sections.text: In Section 2 we define the notations, describe the Nyström method and the ensemble Nyström method, and construct the adversary case for deriving the lower bounds. In Section 3 we establish the lower bounds for the Nyström method and the ensemble Nyström method. In Section 4 we discuss some previous results related to this work. All technical proofs are in the appendix.

sections.heading: 2. Preliminaries
sections.text: In Section 2.1 we introduce the notations used in this paper. In Section 2.2 we briefly describe the Nyström method and the ensemble Nyström method. In Section 2.3 we construct the adversary case which is used throughout this paper for deriving the lower bounds.

sections.heading: 2.1 Notations
sections.text:
For a matrix A = [aij ] ∈ Rm×n, let a(i) be its i-th row, aj be its j-th column, and Ai:j be a submatrix consisting of its i to j-th columns. Moreover, let Im denote the m×m identity matrix, 1m denote an all-one column vector of size m, 1mn denote an m×n all-one matrix, and 0 denote an all-zero matrix with proper size.
Let ρ = rank(A) and k ≤ ρ, the singular value decomposition (SVD) of A can be written as
A =
ρ ∑
i=0
σA,iuA,iv T A,i = UAΣAV T A =
[ UA,k UA,k⊥ ]
[
ΣA 0 0 ΣA,k⊥
] [
VT A,k
VT A,k⊥
]
,
where UA,k, ΣA,k, and VA,k correspond to the top k singular values. We denote Ak = UA,kΣA,kV T A,k which is the closest rank-k approximation to A. We also use σi(A) = σA,i to denote the i-th greatest singular value. When A is positive semidefinite, the SVD is identical to the eigenvalue decomposition and UA = VA.
We define the matrix norms as follows. Let ‖A‖1 = ∑ i,j |aij | be the ℓ1-norm, ‖A‖F = ( ∑
i,j a 2 ij) 1/2 = ∑ i σ 2 A,i be the Frobenius norm, ‖A‖2 = max‖x‖2=1 ‖Ax‖2 = σA,1 be the
spectral norm, and ‖A‖∗ = ∑
i σA,i be the nuclear norm. Furthermore, let A† = VA,ρΣ −1 A,ρU T A,ρ be the Moore-Penrose inverse of A (Ben-Israel and Greville, 2003). When A is nonsingular, the Moore-Penrose inverse is identical to the matrix inverse. Given matrices A ∈ Rm×n, X ∈ Rm×p, and Y ∈ Rq×n, XX†A = UXU T X A ∈ Rm×n is the projection of A onto the column space of X, and AY†Y = AVYV T Y ∈ Rm×n is the projection of A onto the row space of Y.

sections.text:
Given an m×m positive semidefinite matrix

A little differently, the ensemble Nyström method in (Kumar et al., 2009a) selects a collections of t samples, each sample C(i), (i = 1, · · · , t), contains c columns of A. Then the ensemble method combine the samples to construct an approximation

where µ(i) are the weights of the samples. Then the ensemble Nyström method seeks to find out the weights that minimize ‖A − Ãenst,c ‖F or ‖A − Ãenst,c ‖2. A simple but effective strategy is setting the weights to be µ(1) = · · · = µ(t) = 1t .

sections.heading: 3. Main Results
sections.text: We show in this section the lower bounds, both additive and relative, of the Nyström method and the ensemble Nyström method.

sections.heading: 3.1 Lower Bounds of The Standard Nyström Method
sections.text:
Theorem 2 (Additive-error lower bounds of the Nyström method) For a matrix with diagonal entries equal to one and off-diagonal entries equal to α ∈ [0, 1), the approximation error incurred by the Nyström method is lower bounded by
∥ ∥A− Ãnysc ∥ ∥ F ≥ (1− α)

Theorem 3 (Relative-error lower bounds of the Nyström method) The relative-error ratios of the Nyström method are lower bounded by

‖A−CW†CT ‖2 ‖A−Ak‖2 ≥ m+ 1 c+ 1 , ‖A−CW†CT ‖∗ ‖A−Ak‖∗ ≥ m− c m− k ( 1 + 1 c− 1 ) ,

Proof We use the matrix A constructed in (1) and set α = 1/2, then Theorem 3 follow directly from Lemma 1 and Theorem 2.
Remark 4 As for the spectral norm bounds, we will show in Section 4.1 the lower bounds established in Theorem 2 and 3 are better than the previous work of Jin et al. (2011). Actually, relative-error lower bounds in spectral norm and nuclear norm we established are tight because they are attained by some algorithms in (Gittens and Mahoney, 2013, Lemma 4). This will be discussed in Section 4.2.

sections.heading: 3.2 Lower Bounds of The Ensemble Nyström Method
sections.text:
Theorem 5 (Additive-error lower bounds of the ensemble Nyström method) Assume that the ensemble Nyström method selects a collection of t samples, each sample C(i), (i = 1, · · · , t), contains c columns of A without overlapping. For a matrix with all diagonal entries equal to one and off-diagonal entries equal to α ∈ [0, 1), the approximation error incurred by the ensemble Nyström method is lower bounded by
∥ ∥A− Ãenst,c ∥ ∥ F ≥ (1− α)

The relative-error ratio of the ensemble Nyström method is lower bounded by

Remark 7 Theorem 6 shows that, when m ≫ c, k, it is impossible for the ensemble Nyström method to achieve a relative error ratio ‖A−CW†CT ‖2 F
‖A−Ak‖2F ≤ 1 + ǫ unless c is large
enough: c > √ m ǫ +Const. This shows that the ensemble Nyström method does not improve the lower bounds of the Nyström method.

sections.heading: 4. Comparisons with Related Work
sections.text: In Section 4.1 we compare with the previous work of Jin et al. (2011) and show the superiority of our results. In Section 4.2 we show that the relative-error lower bounds in spectral norm and nuclear norm is actually tight for it matches an upper bound exactly. In Section 4.3 we compare the Nyström method with the CUR method and show the downside of the Nyström method.

sections.heading: 4.1 An Additive-Error Lower Bound in Spectral Norm
sections.text:
The previous work of Jin et al. (2011) established a lower error bound for the Nyström method. We show it in the following proposition.
Proposition 8 There exists a positive semidefinite matrix A ∈ Rm×m, where (i) all its diagonal entries are 1, and (ii) the first c+ 1 eigenvalues of A are in the order of Ω(m/c), such that for any sampling strategy that selects c columns to form C, the approximation error of the Nyström method is lower bounded by
∥ ∥A−CW†CT ∥ ∥
2 ≥ Ω
(m
c
)
,
provided that c > 64(log 4)2m2.
Remark 9 This error bound in (Jin et al., 2011, Theorem 4) is not particularly interesting because it lower bounds the approximation error on a matrix with very large norms. According to the construction of A we have that
‖A‖2 = ‖A−Ac‖2 ∼ Ω (m
c
)
,
so the corresponding relative error bounds are ∥
∥A−CW†CT ∥ ∥
2 ‖A−Ac‖2 ∼ O(1).
It is well known that any rank-c approximation Ãapproxc of A obeys ∥
∥A− Ãapproxc ∥ ∥
‖A−Ac‖ ≥ 1.
Thus the error bound in (Jin et al., 2011, Theorem 4) does not actually show how bad the Nyström method can perform compared with the truncated SVD. Furthermore, Theorem 2 in this paper is superior over (Jin et al., 2011, Theorem 4) because Theorem 2 make no assumption on c. In other words, our lower bound still holds when c is small, but (Jin et al., 2011, Theorem 4) fails.

sections.heading: 4.2 Optimal Relative-Error Upper Bounds
sections.text:
The very recent work of Gittens and Mahoney (2013) established several relative-error upper bound for the Nyström method. We show their results in the following proposition.
Proposition 10 Given a positive semidefinite matrix A ∈ Rm×m and an integer k ≤ m, let τ denote the coherence of a dominant k-dimensional invariant subspace of A. Fix a nonzero failure probability δ and accuracy factor ǫ ∈ (0, 1). If c ≥ 2τǫ−2k log(k/δ) columns of A are chosen uniformly at random, then
∥ ∥A−CW†CT ∥ ∥
2 ‖A−Ak‖2 ≤ 1 + m
(1− ǫ)c , ∥ ∥A−CW†CT ∥ ∥
∗ ‖A−Ak‖∗ ≤ 1 + 1 (1− ǫ)δ
hold with probability at least 1− 4δ.
Proposition 10 shows that, when c is large, the relative-error upper bounds in spectral norm and nuclear norm match our lower bounds (Theorem 3) exactly! It indicates that our relative-error lower bounds in spectral norm and nuclear norm are tight and attainable. It also shows the relative-error upper bounds in spectral norm and nuclear norm in Gittens and Mahoney (2013) are near optimal.

sections.heading: 4.3 Relative-Error Upper Bound of CUR
sections.text:
We have discussed in the introduction section that the Nyström method is closely related to the CUR problem. We show in the following proposition that the state-of-the-art CUR algorithm in (Wang and Zhang, 2012) achieved a relative-error ratio of E‖A−CUR‖2 F
‖A−Ak‖2F ≤
1 + 4kc ( 1 + o(1) ) .
Proposition 11 Given a matrix A ∈ Rm×n and a positive integer k ≪ min{m,n}, a CUR algorithm randomly selects c = 4kǫ (1+ o(1)) columns of A to construct C ∈ Rm×c, and then selects r = 4cǫ (1 + o(1)) rows of A to construct R ∈ Rr×n. The relative-error ratio is upper bounded by
E‖A−CUR‖2F = E‖A−C(C†AR†)R‖2F ≤ (1 + ǫ)‖A−Ak‖2F .
It is quite often that the spectrum of a matrix is dominated by several top singular values, so k is usually set to be small. Thus the relative-error upper bound of the CUR algorithm is small. In comparison, the lower bound of the Nyström method is roughly ‖A−Ãnysc ‖2F ‖A−Ak‖2F
≥ 1+ mc2 . Consider that the Nyström method is designed for situations where m is huge, so the lower bound of the Nyström method can be even much worse than the upper bound of CUR! It seems that CUR is a better approximation approach than the Nyström method.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text: We have explored in this paper the lower bounds of the Nyström method and the ensemble Nyström method. This is the first work that conducts a systematic analysis of the lower bounds of the Nyström method. Among the lower bounds we established, two relative-error bounds are tight and attainable, while the tightness of the rest bounds remains unknown. The lower bounds reveals that the Nyström method can be sometimes very bad; the lower error bounds can be even much worse than the upper bound of some CUR algorithms. So we further explored the ensemble Nyström method for a remedy, but only to have found the ensemble Nyström method does not help to improve the lower bounds.

sections.heading: Appendix A. Proof of Lemma 1
sections.text:
Proof The squared Frobenius norm of A is ‖A‖2F = ∑ i,j a 2 ij = m + (m 2 − m)α2. The spectral norm, i.e. the greatest singular value of A is
‖A‖2 = σA,1 = max ‖x‖2≤1 ‖Ax‖2 = 1 +mα− α.
It is also easy to verify that σA,2 = · · · = σA,m. Since ‖A‖2F = ∑m
i=1 σA,i, for any j > 1, we have that
σ2A,j = 1 m− 1 ( ‖A‖2F − σ2A,1 ) = (1− α)2.
So ‖A−Ak‖2 = 1− α for all 1 ≤ k < m. Finally we have that
‖A−Ak‖2F = ‖A‖2F − k ∑
i=1
σ2A,i = (m− k)(1− α)2,
‖A−Ak‖∗ = (m− k)σA,2 = (m− k)(1− α),
‖A‖∗ = m ∑
i=1
σA,i = (1 +mα− α) + (m− 1)(1 − α) = m,
which complete our proofs.

metadata.abstractText: The Nyström method has been widely used to compute low-rank approximations to positive semidefinite matrices. Much work has been done on the sampling techniques for the Nyström method, and many were guaranteed with upper error bounds. However, the lower bounds, especially the relative error bounds, were largely unknown. We explore in this paper the lower bounds of the Nyström method to show how bad the Nyström method can perform. We establish both additive and relative error lower bounds for the Nyström method. Interestingly, some of the relative-error lower bounds we established can be attained by some algorithms, which indicates some lower bounds we establish are tight! However, some lower bounds reveal the downside of the Nyström method that they are much worse than the column selection problem and the CUR problem. Sadly, we also show that some bounds cannot be improved by the ensemble Nyström method.
